Award.AwardTitle: Mechanically-equivalent Response Amplifiers and Frequency Modulators for Energy-harvesting Devices

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
A major obstacle limiting the development of deployable sensing and actuation solutions is the scarcity of power. Converted energy from the vibrations of a host structure using devices (harvesters) based on piezoelectric materials has been shown to be a possible solution. However, these energy harvesters are only efficient at a narrow range of vibration frequencies and/or under high deformation conditions. This considerably limits the levels of harvestable power. While several approaches have been developed to broaden the frequencies at which these vibration-based harvesters can operate, their input still needs to be vibratory. The aim of the proposed research is to be able to harness the energy from quasi-static (very low frequency) structural deformations through novel micro-mechanical devices that use multiple instabilities (sudden transitions in geometry while resisting a compressive load) in elastic elements (strips, plates and shells). The sudden transitions (snap-through instabilities) are recoverable (elastic) and generate high-rate motion that amplify and increase the input frequency and deformation amplitude to scavengers that are attached to the deforming elements. These devices then become mechanical analogs to electrical components (that is, amplifiers and frequency modulators). The research will develop methods to control (occurrence instance and number of events) the snap-through instabilities by optimizing material and geometric configurations on elastic elements, which will in turn allow maximizing the energy transfer from piezoelectric energy harvesters. The investigation will also demonstrate the integration of the developed energy harvesting devices into structural elements, as well as power management and storage approaches to maximize use of locally harvested energy. The introduced methods will allow energy generation and conversion from the unexplored range of quasi-static structural response. The project will allow multidisciplinary training of two graduate students and will be integrated with educational and outreach activities focused on promoting the multidisciplinary training of engineering undergraduate students.

The hypothesis behind the proposed research is that energy harvesting within the unexplored structural response range of << 1Hz can be achieved through devices that amplify the amplitude and frequency of the input signal by means of instability transitions in the post-buckling response of elastic elements. The high rate motion input to the harvester depends on the postbuckling characteristics of the mechanical transducers, which can be controlled through material tailoring, boundary conditions, and system arrangements. Regulation of the post-buckling behavior can lead to controlled acceleration input to the piezoelectric vibrators. The research objective is to advance the knowledge and technology needed to create the noted devices to enhance the power conversion capabilities of piezoelectric materials for energy harvesting under quasi-static structural deformations. The research tasks are: 1) theoretical and experimental studies on the postbuckling response of isotropic and anisotropic columns and cylinders, 2) enhancement and control of the high rate motion of the mechanical transducers by material tailoring, boundary conditions and system assemblies, 3) optimization of the piezoelectric harvesters materials and geometry to tailor the amplitude and magnitude of the output voltage signal, and 4) system integration and evaluation in prototype structural components and evaluation of power management and storage technology. The research work will lead to new concepts and mechanisms for materials and structures that utilize the energy that develops within them (strain) form transient and low magnitude loads and convert it to electrical power for local use or storage. The research will expand the useable range of piezoelectric materials as power harvesters and will also open new possibilities for their use in hybrid material systems s and structures for local powering of sensing and actuating devices as well as displacement-power cogeneration structures.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A major obstacle limiting the wide-spread use of sensors for monitoring the performance and degradation of civil infrastructure is the difficulty and high cost of providing them with power. A promising technology to meet this challenge is to ?harvest? energy from the response of the structures themselves (as they stress, deform and vibrate due to the loads imposed upon them during their normal functions) using piezoelectric vibrating harvesters. Piezoelectric materials can generate electricity when deformed but require that the deformations occur at a high rate. Thus, they are commonly mounted on small vibrating elements (oscillators) that are embedded in, or attached to, a host structure (much larger than the oscillator). Although, piezoelectric vibration harvesters have been widely used, these elements have a narrow natural frequency response range, thus considerably limiting the levels of harvestable power. However, civil structures deform slowly, or quasi-statically, at frequencies much less than 1 Hz, thus considerably limiting the power that can be collected from vibration harvesters

This project addressed the need noted above by developing knowledge and technology for new types of energy harvesting devices that amplify the input frequency to piezoelectric oscillators and make them insensitive to the deformation rate of the host structure. This was achieved by making use of elastic instabilities in slender elements (with dimensions much smaller than the host structure), which permit the accumulation of energy from the slow-deforming structure and release it in ?bursts? during sudden instability transitions to excite mounted piezoelectric oscillators at a much higher desirable frequency. Elastic instabilities are present in slender elements loaded in compression, which, upon reaching a critical point suddenly release energy and change their geometrical configuration to another one that requires less energy. If the element is unrestrained the geometrical change can lead to failure. If constraints are provided, other stable configurations can be achieved and the element can continue to resist load. If the response is elastic the material will not suffer damage and their deformations (and geometry) are recovered upon load removal. The sudden equilibrium state transitions by the elastic elements generate high rate motion that amplify and increase the frequency of the input to piezoelectric scavengers, which are attached to the deforming elements. Since unstable motions due to elastic instabilities are rate-independent of the externally applied deformation, the hypothesis that drove this research project is that elastic instabilities can be used as the fundamental mechanism for energy harvesting to overcome the disadvantage of piezoelectric vibration-based energy harvesters with a narrow frequency response range (and thus limiting the levels of harvested power) to effectively scavenge energy directly from quasi-static (frequencies much less than 1 Hz) structural deformations.

Through experimental, numerical, and analytical tasks, this research project demonstrated that instabilities in elastic systems (postbuckling and snap-buckling events) can be effectively used as energy concentrators that release their stored strain energy into sudden bursts of kinetic energy, which can then be used for energy harvesting purposes. Means to modify and control the elastic postbuckling response (spacing between buckling transitions during loading/deformation and their physical location) of axially loaded bilaterally constrained columns/strips were also developed through the design of non-prismatic columns/strips, the use of non-uniform lateral constraints, and through designs of multiple strips/columns (i.e., assemblies.) The ability to control and tailor the elastic postbuckling response leads to enhanced performance of the energy harvesting devices based on the studied concept.

Studies on the size dependence of buckling and postbuckling behavior of microbeams showed that the size of the beam does not affect its stiffness, but that it significantly reduces the deflection during buckling and increases the forces at which buckling transitions occur. Theoretical models based on energy-methods were developed alongside experimental and numerical efforts to predict the corresponding strain of the strip?s buckled configuration for the purpose of calculating the electrical energy generation. The analytical models allow accurate prediction on the axial strain caused by the buckled configuration of the strip as a function of its axial shortening. The concept of controlled elastic instabilities for energy harvesting was also employed on a prototyped device consisting of a bilaterally constrained column with a bonded unimorph piezoelectric layer, which it was shown capable of adequately providing power supply for low-power budget devices.

Outreach educational activities for K-12 students were developed and conducted biannually. The events consisted on lectures related to the history of structural engineering, concepts on materials and structures, concepts on structural design and then a hands-on activity on which they need to optimize the design of a bridge model and conduct a physical test. Knowledge generated from the project was disseminated through journal and conference publications, and technical presentations. The project provided support for the research training of a post-doctoral researcher, three Ph.D. students, one M.S. student, and one undergraduate student.
